title: 108_s2584
content: The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" allows for a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a 50% credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year. The maximum credit for property placed in service by an eligible person is $30,000. The maximum credit for property placed in service by an eligible person is $30,000, reduced by creditable investments. For property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity, the credit cannot exceed the sum of the eligible person's investments in the entity. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments are the qualified investments made by the person in the entity, minus previous investments taken into account for other properties. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is reduced by the sum of the qualified investments made by the person in the entity and other farmer-owned entities, with a limitation on the total investments made. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is reduced by the qualified investments made by the eligible person, with a limit of $30,000 per year. Qualified value-added agricultural property is defined as property used to add value to goods derived from organic matter. Qualified value-added agricultural property is property used to add value to goods derived from organic matter, with a useful life of 3 years or more. The term 'eligible person' refers to someone who materially participates in an eligible farming business during the taxable year. This participation is determined based on their involvement in the trade or business. The term 'eligible person' refers to someone who materially participates in an eligible farming business during the taxable year. Material participation in farming is determined similarly to section 2032A(e)(6) for corporations, cooperatives, partnerships, estates, or trusts at the shareholder, partner, or beneficial interests level. An 'eligible farming business' is defined as a farming business according to section. "A farmer-owned entity is a corporation where eligible persons own at least 50% of the total voting power and stock value." "A farmer-owned entity includes a corporation, partnership, or cooperative where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or profits interests." The text discusses the definition of a farmer-owned entity, which includes a corporation, partnership, or cooperative where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or profits interests. Constructive ownership rules apply, with family members defined as spouses, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. The family of an individual includes their spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, as well as the spouses of their children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren who reside in the same household or jointly operate farming businesses. Adopted children are treated the same as biological children. The tax code defines businesses and qualified investments, including the purchase of a qualified equity interest in a farmer-owned entity. Adopted children are treated the same as biological children in terms of family relationships. The tax code defines a qualified equity interest as stock in a domestic corporation, capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, or patronage interest in a cooperative acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. The tax code specifies that a qualified equity interest includes stock in a domestic corporation, capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, or patronage interest in a cooperative acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Special rules apply for married individuals filing separately. For married individuals filing separately, the tax credit amount is reduced to $15,000 instead of $30,000. Rules for allocation of credit for estates and trusts apply. Certain properties are not eligible for the credit. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by the amount of the credit allowed and any recapture. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by the amount of the credit allowed and any recapture within a 5-year period of placing the property in service. Within a 5-year period of placing qualified value-added agricultural property in service, certain conditions apply to eligible persons, including ceasing to qualify, disposing of the property, or no longer being eligible. Special rules apply in the event of death, suspending the period for an eligible person.
